modules.description: type t = { x : float; y : float };; Provides functions to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points, scale a point by a scalar factor, and translate a point by a vector. Works with floating-point coordinates in a 2D plane. Used in graphics rendering to adjust object positions and compute movement vectors.

type t = { x : float; y : float; z : float } Provides vector addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, and dot product operations. Works with 3D coordinate structures represented as records with x, y, and z components. Used to calculate physical forces in a simulation or transform object positions in a 3D graphics engine.

The module provides low-level controls for graphics rendering and user interaction, managing animation states, OpenGL lists, and mouse/window coordinates through plot objects, views, and GL handlers. It includes functions for adjusting rendering settings, handling UI state, and managing system configurations like point size adjustments and lighting toggles, supporting tasks such as real-time visualization and event-driven GUI development. Specific use cases involve optimizing OpenGL pipelines and ensuring compatibility with external tools.

Combines 2D and 3D point and vector operations, offering structured representations for planar and spatial coordinates. Supports distance calculation, scaling, translation, and vector arithmetic including addition, subtraction, and dot products. Enables precise geometric transformations and physical simulations. For example, it can compute the distance between two 2D points or calculate the resultant force vector from multiple 3D vectors.

Manages plot definitions and rendering through a structured sheet of graphical objects, supporting 2D and 3D visualizations, annotations, and animations. Key data types include sheets, views, and plot objects, with operations for drawing lines, points, surfaces, and text, as well as controlling display timing and color. Examples include generating 3D mountain plots, animating rotating surfaces, and overlaying text on coordinate systems. Functions also handle OpenGL rendering, user interactions, and system-level adjustments for visualization accuracy.

Provides functions to generate and manipulate parametric curves and Cartesian functions, supporting float-based x and y values. Includes operations for sampling, scaling, and transforming plotted data. Used to create visual representations of mathematical functions and curves in graphical applications.

Provides tools for geometric computations and visualization, combining 2D and 3D coordinate operations with plot management. It includes data types for points, vectors, sheets, and plot objects, supporting transformations, distance calculations, and rendering of complex graphical scenes. Users can generate 3D surfaces, animate objects, and overlay annotations with precise control over appearance and timing. Operations like vector addition and surface plotting enable both mathematical analysis and high-quality graphical output.
